section.title: Export data
section.para: You can export the data of the result set into local files of the following formats:

itemizedlist.listitem: SQL statements (INSERT, UPDATE or DELETE & INSERT)
Tab separated text file. Columns are separated with a tab, rows are separated with a newline character

section.para: To save the data from the current result set into an external file, choose DataSave Data as You will be prompted for the filename. On the right side of the file dialog you will have the possibility to define the type of the export. The export parameters on the right side of the dialog are split into two parts. The upper part defines parameters that are available for all export types. These are the encoding for the file, the format for date and date/time data and the columns that should be exported.
All format specific options that are available in the lower part, are also available when using the WbExport command. For a detailed discussion of the individual options please refer to that section.

The options SQL UPDATE and SQL DELETE/INSERT are only available when the current result has a single table that can be updated, and the primary key columns for that table could be retrieved. If the current result does not have key columns defined, you can select the key columns that should be used when creating the file. If the current result is retrieved from multiple tables, you have to supply a table name to be used for the SQL statements.

Please keep in mind that exporting the data from the result set requires you to load everything into memory. If you need to export data sets which are too big to fit into memory, you should use the WbExport command to either create SQL scripts or to save the data as text or XML files that can be imported into the database using the WbImport command. You can also use SQLExport query result to export the result of the currently selected SQL statement.

section.title: Copy data to the clipboard
section.para:
You can also copy the data from the result into the system clipboard in four different formats. In any case default settings are used for the various options of the respective format.
Text (tab separated)
This will use a tab as the column separator, and will not quote any values. The end-of-line sequence will be a newline (Unix style) and the column headers will be part of the copied data. Special characters (e.g. newlines) in the actual data will not be replaced (as it is possible with the WbExport command).
When you hold down the Shift key when you select the menu item, the column headers will not be copied to the clipboard. When you hold down the Ctrl key when selecting the menu item, you can choose which columns should be copied to the clipboard. Pressing Shift and Ctrl together is also supported.
SQL (INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE & INSERT)
The end-of-line sequence will be a newline (Unix style). No cleanup of data will be done as it is possible with the WbExport command, apart from correctly quoting single quotes inside the values (which is required to generate valid SQL)

As with the Save Data as command, the options SQL UPDATE and SQL DELETE/INSERT are only available when the current result set is updateable. If no key columns could be retrieved for the current result, you can manually define the key columns to be used, using Data Define key columns
section.note: If you do not want to copy all columns to the clipboard, hold down the the CTRL key while selecting one of the menu items related to the clipboard. A dialog will then let you select the columns that you want to copy.
section.para: Alternatively you can hold down the Alt key while selecting rows/columns in the result set. This will allow you to select only the columns and rows that you want to copy. If you then use one of the formats available in the Copy selected submenu, only the selected cells will be copied. If you choose to copy the data as UPDATE or DELETE/INSERT statements, the generated SQL statements will not be correct if you did not select the primary key of the underlying update table.

section.title: Import data
section.para: &wb-productname; can import tab separated text files into the current result set. This means, that you need to issue the approriate SELECT statement first. The structure of the file has to match the structure of the result set, otherwise an error will occur. To initiate the import select DataImport
When selecting the file, you can change some parameters for the import:

entry.para: if this option this is checked, the first line of the import file will be ignored
the delimiter used to separate column values. Enter \t for the tab character
The format in which date fields are specified.
The character that is used to indicate the decimals in numeric values (typically a dot or a comma)
The character used to quote values with special characters. Make sure that each opening quote is followed by a closing quote in your text file.

section.para: You can also import text and XML files using the WbImport command. Using the WbImport command is the recommended way to import data, as it is much more flexible, and - more important - it does not read the data into memory.

section.title: XML Export and Import
section.para: You can use &wb-productname;'s XML files to copy data from one system to another.

You need to create the XML file first, using the WbExpor command from within the workbench, beeing connected to the source system. Suppose your data is stored in the table PERSON on your source system and you want to only select the columns lastname, firstname, birthday to be transferred to your target system.
To create the XML file the following command should be used:
section.programlisting: WbExport -type=xml -file="c:/data/person.xml" -table=contact; SELECT lastname, firstname, birthday FROM person;
section.para: As the data should be imported into the table CONTACT the -table=contact parameter is passed to the EXPORT command. You can achieve the same, by editing the XML file afterwards and change the contents of of the <table-name> tag.
Once the XML file is generated, you can connect to your source system and import the file with the following command:

&wb-productname; will read the XML file and insert every row into the table CONTACT of the database. AS the XML format generated by &wb-productname; includes the internal long value for date objects, it is not necessary to set the date or datetime format when importing the data. If you have a file with a lot of rows, you might want to set the parameter -commitevery=n. Some DBMS work faster if you commit more frequently instead of commit a huge number of inserts at the end. Please refer to the WbExport command for more details.

If you have XML files in a different format then the one expected by &wb-productname; you can transform the file via XSLT into the correct format. More details on how to transform XML files to and from &wb-productname; can be found in the description of the XSLT command and the WbExport command
If you want to copy data from one database to another, you can also use the WbCopy command, or the DataPumper tool

section.title: Compressing export files
section.para: The WbExport command supports compressing of the generated output files. This includes the actually export file and any associated BLOB files.
